title: 114_hr3484
content: The Act titled "Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016" authorizes certain leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families, including supportive housing, health promotion, education, and vocational training. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families, including health promotion, education, vocational training, peer activities, legal assistance, volunteerism, family support services, transportation, and services supporting these purposes. Additionally, a lease of real property for up to 10 years to The Regents of the University of California, on behalf of its UCLA campus, is allowed. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families. A lease of real property for up to 10 years to The Regents of the University of California, on behalf of its UCLA campus, is allowed if services to veterans are the main focus. The Regents must also agree to provide additional services for veterans during the lease term. The Secretary may allow The Regents of the University of California to lease real property at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for up to 10 years, with a focus on providing additional services and support for veterans and their families. These services must primarily benefit severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless veterans, and may include medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling activities. The Regents must maintain records documenting the value of these services. The Secretary may not carry out any land-sharing agreement at the Campus unless it provides additional health-care resources to the Campus, benefits veterans and their families, and does not generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Revenues from leases at the Campus are credited to the Department medical facilities account for use without fiscal year limitation. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus for public transportation facilities and to the State of California, County of Los Angeles. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus for public transportation facilities and utilities, subject to appropriate terms and conditions. Easements or rights-of-way will be terminated upon abandonment or nonuse. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus for public transportation facilities and utilities, subject to appropriate terms and conditions. Easements or rights-of-way authorized shall be terminated upon abandonment or nonuse, with all rights reverting to the United States. The Secretary is prohibited from selling or conveying fee simple title to any real property or improvements at the Campus. Leases must be consistent with the approved master plan and comply with relevant laws. The Secretary must comply with all Federal laws related to leases and land use at the Campus. If significant mismanagement is found, no new leases or land-sharing agreements can be entered into until all recommendations from the audit report are implemented. The Secretary must ensure compliance with Federal laws regarding leases and land use at the Campus. A Community Veterans Engagement Board will be established to coordinate with the Department of Veterans Affairs locally. The Secretary will establish a Community Veterans Engagement Board to coordinate locally with the Department of Veterans Affairs, comprised of members including veterans and nonveterans to provide advice and recommendations for improving services and outcomes for veterans, members of the Armed Forces, and their families. The Board will also provide opportunities for community collaboration and communication. The Secretary will establish a Community Veterans Engagement Board comprised of members who are family members of veterans, veteran advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. The Board will collaborate with the community, focus on local issues related to health care, benefits, and memorial services at the Campus, and notify Congress about lease agreements at the Campus. The Secretary will notify Congress and relevant committees before entering into or renewing leases at the Campus. An annual report evaluating all leases and land-sharing agreements will be submitted to Congress and members representing the area where the Campus is located. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs will submit reports on all leases at the Campus to relevant committees every two and five years after the enactment of the Act. The Inspector General will provide reports on leases and land management at the Campus to relevant committees, considering the Secretary's previous reports. The Secretary retains authority to enter into agreements for the Campus as long as they comply with the law and this section. The Secretary can enter agreements for the Campus as long as they comply with the law and this section. The term "principally benefit veterans and their families" is defined as services exclusively for veterans and their families, excluding services that only generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016 provides services primarily for veterans and their families, excluding those that solely generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Conforming amendments prohibit property disposal and enhance-use leases under this Act.
